From what I've noticed:   Coby White up to 6-5 from 6-4.  Wendell Carter up to 6-10 from 6-9.  BI up to 6-8 from 6-7.  DMitch down to 6-0 from 6-1. You're not looking at WHO we've been missing. De'Andre Hunter, Cam Reddish, and Kris Dunn have not played in months except for two games Hunter came back for. Those are our three best perimeter defenders. When we had Hunter and Reddish both healthy and playing we were a top ten defense. Since then we were like 22nd or something the last time I checked. You made the point that you hide a poor defender by surrounding him with good defenders. Well, we have done that. They've just been injured for months lmao.

I made a comment similar to yours down below. This guy linked an article that had Trae as the worst defender in the league last season to argue that Trae wasn't one of the top players in the league. I made the point that Booker was second on that list but anyone who wouldn't call Booker a top player in the league is stupid.   You're absolutely right. We were a top 10 defense at the beginning of the season before De'Andre Hunter went down. We have been missing our THREE best perimeter defenders for months. It'll be no surprise when we have those guys healthy again next season Trae's numbers will improve just like Bookers.

Every NBA podcast i listen to has done 15+ minutes on how great de'andre hunter is and how he made the jump this year and atlanta found a real one and its such a disaster for the hawks that they lost their star prospect to an injury... which i generally agree with.  Yet almost none of these experts mention RJ even though his stats are basically identical with about 20 more games in a less talented offense while being key to a much better defense, and he's 3 years younger than Hunter, picked 1 spot ahead of him in the draft.  just seems like because he was a highly touted prospect in high school people decided he was a bust when to me he looks like a quality starter and fringe allstar by his age 21 season.  compare his sophmore season to beale's or tatum's.  this guy just seems destined to be an excellent pro who quietly gets better every year.
I don't see how you could put De'Andre Hunter over Keldon, and I was Hunter's biggest fan at Virginia

This was my first time playing fantasy, long time gambling addict and degenerate so I knew a lot but I had some growing pains, especially in an 18 man league. I took KAT, he went down with his wrist, then covid, traded him and Lavine (rip), and Lamarcus Aldridge (dodged a bullet) for Beal, De'Andre Hunter (went down for the entire season pretty much for me) Divencenzo.. eventually I ended up with Giannis and Sabonis which has been huge for me; I've lucked out on a lot of waiver wire players, Moses Brown, Bruce Brown, Diallo had a hot streak for me, etc.  The easiest way to win in fantasy is to punt 4 categories. I try to go for FG%, rebounds, blocks, steals, and then the last one is usually a toss up for assists or t/o's (I have Draymond.. Dray+Sabonis+Giannis has given me so many assists this season)  Next time I'll be able to hone in on that fifth category lol. Sometimes I win ft% even.

Hawks gotta be up there. You're losing Trae, Clint, and JC.  LouWill, Bogi, Gallo, De'Andre Hunter, Nathan "The Dark" Knight, Kevin "So Big It Might" Huerter, Cam Reddish, Tony Snell, Okongwu all left over. Pick your poison

Since Nate Mcmillan took over, March 1st for reference, the hawks are tied for 4th with the Celtics in offense, and we're 14th in defense, Celtics are 21.   That's with de'andre hunter missing all but 2 of those games, he's our best wing on offense and defense. Reddish has missed all of them, he's our 2nd best wing defender. Dunn has missed every game this season, but theoretically he's our best guard defender. Collins has missed 9 games, Trae has missed 4 games, Gallo has missed 4 or 5 games, Capela has missed 2-3 games.  We've been incredibly injured and we're still performing well. I absolutely think we had a good chance against the Celtics if we can manage to get healthy before the end of the season. To call us just the 24th defense when all of our best defenders, other than Capela, have missed that many games is very weird, especially since we've made drastic changes since the start of the season when we ran a different defense under a much worse head coach.
i personally think  De'Andre Hunter  is more important to us than jc but jc is a good big man

> Bron was the consensus best player in the world at the time.   Not to MVP voters, and not for the better part of a decade.  >Are you really going to argue that AD was fine with Boston?  Your link quotes anonymous sources.  Mine quotes Davis.  Try again.  >, it was understood that it wasn’t a rental.  Rank nonsense.  "Where he’s going to land? I have no idea,” Paul told SI. “And it don’t matter. We’re going into free agency. Why does it matter to me where he goes? Earth: We’re going into free agency. He has a year, he has to play. But after that, I can’t say it no bigger: WE ARE GOING INTO FREE AGENCY. 2020: ANTHONY DAVIS WILL BE IN FREE AGENCY.” --https://www.si.com/nba/2019/06/12/anthony-davis-free-agency-2020-pelicans-trade-rumors  >I don’t know why people think this...  Well, being as thoroughly stupid as you are, I am sure there's a long list of things that you don't understand, but I haven't the time nor the desire to explain them all to you.  And it wasn't 7 picks, either, which you ought to know, but obviously do not.  >JA and levert are also a lot more valuable than Zo and hart were.  What a pathetic attempt.  You forgot the best player involved, and De'andre Hunter, who are both more valuable than anything Brooklyn traded for two years of Harden.

You forgot De'Andre Hunter, too.  They'd have a ton of talent, but would require a clever coach to manage it all effectively.  That's a much nicer problem to have versus having insufficient talent, though.

>Other than Zion and Ja I dont think theres anyone in that draft class with more potential than him.   RJ/Okeke/Rui/De'Andre Hunter/Herro are some players off the top of my head that I think has more potential.

>Agree to disagree.  My understanding is we got Lebron and management realized we had a championship window.  They saw the young core play for a few years and decided that wasn’t their best chance to win a chip, AD was.  I agree that is what happened.  >There may or may not have been some other move to make, but Butler doesn’t compliment Lebron nearly as well as AD does.   Arguably true, but Butler would've cost 1/10th as much to acquire, so really, who cares?  And James can seemingly play with anyone.  >Some people will see it as a bad move I guess, but you’re in the minority.  I obviously am in the minority, but that doesn't mean I'm wrong.  >If we win again this year, are you going to admit it was a good move? Or will you still be on the “hasn’t paid off yet” tip?   First off, whatever the Lakers win in this and subsequent years is really irrelevant.  Davis was a UFA this past December, and could've signed with anyone, Los Angeles included.  There was absolutely no need to spend a decade of assets to acquire him unless you believed the window was just 1 year -- in which case, again, that was way too much to spend for one title.  That said, I would not consider two rings "paid off", no.  As I said, historically, the Lakers win 2.3 titles every 10 years.  And they traded an entire decade of assets for Davis.  Two titles would be getting close, but if it winds up being a title last year and this year, followed by 10 years of bad teams, I am calling that no better than a mediocre trade.  There are many variables.  Maybe De'Andre Hunter never makes it back from his leg injury.  Maybe Lonzo Ball never gets any better.  Maybe those 3 first-round picks all wind up being late-twenties picks in shallow drafts.  Those are all possibilities.  On the other hand, Ingram is already an All-star, and putting up better numbers this year than Davis is.  And Ball is still younger than, say, Larry Bird was as a rookie -- not that they compare as players.  And Hunter was posting 17 ppg for Atlanta, and hasn't played a full season yet.  If all three of those guys wind up All-stars, and a couple of the first-round picks are very good players, then that trade looks really quite bad.  >Personally I’m ecstatic that I get to watch Lebron and AD for years to come, calf strain and all.   Hopefully Davis winds up playing more, and not an expensive disabled-player-exception.

He's been playing *pretty good* defense.   He hasn't been all-defense level.   Both Blazers forwards have been better defenders. Both Suns forwards have been better defenders. Both Clippers wings are better. Harrison Barnes and Lu Dort and OG have all been better. Royce has been better. De'Andre Hunter has been fantastic. Oladipo's been better.   He's playing above average wing defense, that's true. But he is nowhere near a top two defender in the NBA at his position. That's moronic.

There's been injuries to role players as well, they just don't get nearly as much attention. But Danny Green, KCP, De'Andre Hunter, Donte DiVincenzo, Alex Caruso, Will Barton, Serge Ibaka, etc all have missed time with injuries in these playoffs.
Their no.1 defender is missing. De'andre Hunter made Randle's life miserable and probably stripped him off a max contract.

I've watched maybe 5-10 games of theirs so I can't match that eye test but I would say that while you're right that Cam is more disruptive, more disruptive doesn't always mean a better defender.   The Hawks' defense was [6.9](https://www.basketball-reference.com/players/h/huntede01/on-off/2021) points better per 100 possessions with Hunter on the court versus [4.8](https://www.basketball-reference.com/players/r/reddica01/on-off/2021) points worse with Cam on the court. I'm assuming they usually play with similar guys so that's a pretty big difference.  Also, De'Andre beats Cam in every advanced stat and I think gives you better rim protection so more versatility on the defensive end.

>It would be Lebron, Kuzma, Caruso, THT, DLo, Josh Hart, Ingram, Nance, Lonzo, Randle, Clarkson and Thomas Bryant; rest would be guys on the min.  You forgot:  * De'Andre Hunter, the #4 overall pick who they traded for Davis * Ivica Zubac, who they traded to make room for Davis * Moe Wagner, who they traded for Davis * Isaac Bonga, who they traded for Davis * Jemarrio Jones, who they also traded for Davis -- but is a G Leaguer who makes no difference, just mentioning him for completeness  >Very thin on big men  Not so thin when you include Zubac, and to a lesser degree Wagner.  If they somehow had all those players, they'd have the deepest roster in the league by far.  Hunter and Zubac both routinely start for playoff teams, and you didn't even include them.  Their bench would be a playoff team in the East.  The huge challenge would be finding minutes for everyone, and getting all these players to mesh offensively -- both are which are parts of coaching that Frank Vogel struggles terribly with.  Luckily for Vogel, with the most talent in the league, there would probably be many good choices on how to play them, so he might accidentally stumble across a few excellent lineups.

The Hawks hit gold in the 2017-2019 drafts.  * John Collins (2017, 19th pick) * Trae Young (2018, 5th pick) * Kevin Huerter (2018, 19th pick) * De'Andre Hunter (2019, 4th pick, moved up by trading up with New Orleans) * Cam Reddish (2019, 10th pick, obtained from Luka Traed) * Onyeka Okongwu (2020, 6th pick, TBD how valuable of a contributor he can be)  Getting Taurean Prince (12th pick) and De'Andre Bembry (21st pick) in 2016 could have gone worse, too. Real minefield in that draft, with Papagiannis (13th), Yabusele (16th), Baldwin (17th), Ellenson (18th), Malachi Richardson (22nd), Zizic (23rd), Brice Johnson (25th) lurking. That doesn't even include Dragan Bender (4th), Kris Dunn (5th), Marquese Chriss (8th), and Thon Maker (10th). Bruno Fernando has been a letdown, but he was the 34th pick, so expectations can't be too high.  And somehow, they have positive draft capital moving forward (i.e. didn't sacrifice their picks unnecessarily).  Having all these guys on rookie deals means they were able to sign or acquire a bunch of vets to fill in their roster holes: Gallinari, Bogdanovic, Capela, Lou Will, and Solo. Their cap also allowed them to act as cap relief for other teams. Schlenk has done wonders for this team since his 2017 arrival. He apparently also scouted Draymond when he was working for the Warriors.
Bogdan has a bad knee and they're missing De'Andre Hunter as well.
The Hawks had their own injuries though. Cam Reddish missed the entire Knicks and Sixers series. De'Andre Hunter has missed the whole playoffs.

Lakers won a championship with AD while the Pelicans can't make the playoffs even with Zion posting some gaudy scoring & efficiency stats. Lakers will do that trade again every single time, they honestly didn't give up that much.   Pelicans got the headline pieces of Ingram/Ball/Hart/Hunter + 2021, 2023 & 2024 1st rounders. They later flipped De'Andre Hunter for Hayes & NAW  Wizards got a bunch of pointless bench fodder (Wagner, Bonga & Jones) + 2022 2nd round pick to send cash to the Pelicans.

Just to counter, I don't think we played all that well today. We came out hot from 3 but it's still noticeable how hard Trae has to work to keep the team in the game with Bogi being hampered and without De'Andre to help out. Also our defense has been a step off without Hunter. We're really missing his length on the outside and letting way too many guys get open looks.
Healthy hawks...they're missing De'Andre Hunter.  Anyways, this is moot. The Suns and Bucks have been the two healthiest teams; that's why it's most likely going to be the finals.

There's a difference between being fatigued or sore and having a tweaked knee that pulled you out of the second half of a game. Bogdan has very, very obviously been playing much worse ever since it happened. That kind of sudden switch isn't a fatigue thing. Remember the Hawks are also missing our best perimeter defender (who was also putting up 10+ a game against the Knicks before he was listed as out for the year) in De'Andre Hunter. Saying a 100% healthy Hawks are clearly a worse team than the Bucks is just ignorance or favoritism.

Injuries happen though, that's part of the equation to winning a championship. You not only need to play the best ball, but be the healthiest team as well. Even the teams left have injury issues. Kawhi, donte for the bucks, de'andre hunter for the hawks, cp3 with covid and the shoulder thing, even guys like trae, dbook, and giannis are banged up. Imo this year is one of the harder years to win one with the quick turnaround after the bubble.
A little of both. We are also missing our second best player, De'Andre Hunter

Trae was stuck on a really really bad Hawks team for the last few years. Between Collins and Huerter developing, the signing of Gallinari and Bogdanovic, and the trade for Capela, he finally has a team around him that allows him to be the elite playmaker that he is. With a healthy De'Andre Hunter and Cam Reddish, this team should be a contender for years to come.
If they play the Hawks, this will also be true (De'Andre Hunter)

Bogdan came back from a long injury absence and played incredibly well to close out the season, so that was sort of a change.   But they also lost De'Andre Hunter around the same time, so that kind of evens out in terms of roster assets. It really does just feel like significantly better coaching

So he's good at leveraging teams with MVP superstars into trading for his own team's stars and not much else.

I'm not disputing the fact that they had great offseasons. All of those teams got better, but so did we.   We were one of the most injured teams in the league last year. Honestly we should probably be talking about how we added De'Andre Hunter and Cam Reddish to our roster. Hunter played 23 games and Cam played 26. Even Bogi only played 44 games. We're also coming into the season with much better options at the backup 1 spot. Whatever positives Rondo brought to our team off the court, he was absolutely abysmal on the court. Staring the season with Sweet Lou and Delon Wright coming off the bench is a huge improvement for us.   Also, as others have pointed out we might as well be a completely different team with Nate coaching. I get that you can't just throw out our record under LP, but what we did in the playoffs proved that our regular season record under Nate wasn't some fluke.

I like this one too, been thinking the same thing:   * They'll have a full season with McMillan, which will help them gel a bit more. Not only that, but they won 68.4% of their games with Nate last year, that's 56 win pace in a full, 82-game season.  * De'Andre Hunter will be back and healthy, people forget they were missing a starter who played like one of the best 3&D wings to start the season.  * They brought back LouWill, who was a nice bench spark plug last year, drafted Sharife Cooper to give them some backup playmaking, picked up Gorgui Dieng (who's a reliable backup C) and Delon Wright (a really solid defensive guard), and they have a ton of high-potential guys like Cam Reddish/Jalen Johnson/Onkeya Okongwu who could break out.

I'm not tossing out how bad Trae is on defense, I'm saying the on-court impact of Guard defense isn't close to offense.   Being a +6 on offense and a -4 on defense does not actually play out to only making your team +2 better, because that -4 can be mitigated in ways that offensive production can't be manufactured.  That's why I brought up the fact that Trae is in multiple of the Hawks best defensive rated lineups, and when De'Andre Hunter was healthy, the Hawks were a top half defensive team.

Last gm drafted him and with Casey as the couch it was a poor situation; Sekou was a raw prospect but Casey doesn't want to give guys the minutes to develop. Bad team or not, Casey wants to do everything he can to win the game in front of him. Then Jerami Grant, who plays the same position, became the de facto franchise player. Saddiq Bey is older and more developed than Sekou; his skillset is what you want from a role player, so he naturally jumped in the rotation.   Sekou also dealt with random injuries like concussions that kept him out and missed valuable learning minutes because of the pandemic. Remember that between March and December of 2020, he didn't play organized basketball.   His summer league wasn't good. He had a big game but for the most part he blended into the court. You're expecting more from a 3rd year player in summer league. On the other hand, he's still only 20 years old. For comparison: Saddiq Bey (22), Jalen Smith (21),  De'Andre Hunter (23), Brandon Ingram (23), Davion Mitchell (23), Chris Duarte (24), Tey Murphy (21), Ayo Dosunmu (22), Pascal Siakam (27). I don't think it's fair to write him off yet, but if he's going to grow it wasn't going to be in Detroit.

> Why would i be happy for anyone's team's success at the expense of mine?  As a fan? No reason.  As a commentator?  People bitch endlessly about the Warriors commentators, but they get genuinely hype for great basketball play no matter which team is doing it.  The Warriors commentators will say the Warriors fouled if they fouled, will credit opposing teams for great offensive or defensive play.  If the Warriors lose because an opposing player just went nuclear, they'll appreciate the great skill on display.  Sole exception is James Harden. If he's being a flopping bitch, Bob will complain about the flopping. The one time Harden beat the Warriors by playing great instead of flopping, Bob bitched about how he could be *this good* if he tried but he just flops all the time?  And honestly, I was thinking the same thing.  I can't stand commentary teams that are so homer they can't admit another team's player did something good, that can't just be like, "Hey, 50 points and 10 assists, that's an amazing game by Steph Curry right there."  Like earlier in this game Bob Fitzgerald was talking about how great he thinks De'Andre Hunter is and was *really sad about it* when Hunter turned the ball over. It's possible to be a homer commentator and still *appreciate your opponents as skilled basketball players*.
Let De'Andre Hunter cook.
Sounds like you needed THE De'andre Hunter instead of the "De'andre" hunter.   Common mistake.
